all_text_timv: Burrow, James, 1701-1782. James Burrow letter to the Earl of Macclesfield. Letter from Iames Burrow esquire to the Earl of Macclesfield upon the subject of pointing 1755 January 1. 15 pages : marbled paper ; 21 cm text txt rdacontent unmediated n rdamedia volume nc rdacarrier In Rare Books and Manuscripts, University Libraries, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa. (#RBM 9557/Mss. book 25) Unrestricted access. James Burrow writes to the Earl of Macclesfield after reading John Ward's book, Die ratione interpungendi, with his observations about punctuation. Sir James Burrow (28 November 1701- 5 November 1782 at Starborough Castle, Lingfield, Surrey), was a Legal Reporter at Inner Temple, London, and was Vice President and twice briefly President of the Royal Society. He was knighted in 1773. As a legal reporter, he wrote and published reports of the decisions of significant cases of the English legal system. Formerly part of an 18th-century library in Williamscote House near Banbury, Oxfordshire, England, assembled by John Loveday (1711-1789), philologist and antiquary, who lived at Caversham in Oxfordshire. The library was moved to Williamscote House in 1799 by John Loveday the second (1742-1809), Doctor of Laws. Ward, John, approximately 1679-1758. Die ratione interpungendi. English language Punctuation. Letters (correspondence) aat Ward, John, approximately 1679-1758, transcriber. Macclesfield, George Parker, Earl of, approximately 1697-1764, recipient.

administrative_history_note_ssm: Sir James Burrow (28 November 1701- 5 November 1782 at Starborough Castle, Lingfield, Surrey), was a Legal Reporter at Inner Temple, London, and was Vice President and twice briefly President of the Royal Society. He was knighted in 1773. As a legal reporter, he wrote and published reports of the decisions of significant cases of the English legal system.
provenance_note_ssm: Formerly part of an 18th-century library in Williamscote House near Banbury, Oxfordshire, England, assembled by John Loveday (1711-1789), philologist and antiquary, who lived at Caversham in Oxfordshire. The library was moved to Williamscote House in 1799 by John Loveday the second (1742-1809), Doctor of Laws.
